question: Is ozanezumab effective for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis?
ideal_answer: No. Ozanezumab did not show efficacy compared with placebo in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. Therefore, Nogo-A does not seem to be an effective therapeutic target in ALS.

snippets.text: The adjusted mean of the joint-rank score was -14·9 (SE 13·5) for the ozanezumab group and 15·0 (13·6) for the placebo group, with a least squares mean difference of -30·0 (95% CI -67·9 to 7·9; p=0·12).
INTERPRETATION: Ozanezumab did not show efficacy compared with placebo in patients with ALS. Therefore, Nogo-A does not seem to be an effective therapeutic target in ALS.

INTERPRETATION

Ozanezumab did not show efficacy compared with placebo in patients with ALS.

The adjusted mean of the joint-rank score was -14·9 (SE 13·5) for the ozanezumab group and 15·0 (13·6) for the placebo group, with a least squares mean difference of -30·0 (95% CI -67·9 to 7·9; p=0·12).
INTERPRETATION Ozanezumab did not show efficacy compared with placebo in patients with ALS.

The adjusted mean of the joint-rank score was -14·9 (SE 13·5) for the ozanezumab group and 15·0 (13·6) for the placebo group, with a least squares mean difference of -30·0 (95% CI -67·9 to 7·9; p=0·12).
